Dear Graydon:*
Thank you for your good letter of December lig¬
and your kind comments on the testimony in Washing¬
ton*
I am going to have to plead a slight delay before
I supply you with the NAEB information* I returned
from Washington to find things in a considerable
jangle here since my Operations Manager had betaken
himself to the hospital with a severe attack of
ulcerative colitis and following lis entry there,
his secretary who was well informed in how to deal
with networks, herself took ill and was hospitalized,
so I have been trying to pick up the pieces with
considerable difficulty*
If you can wait until after the middle of Jan¬
uary for this material, I can turn you out a fair
job', but I do not think I can put my mind to any¬
thing until we get the mechanics of local operation
cleared up*
I donft know if I told you, but we run the tele¬
vision station from 1:30 in the afternoon until 11:00
at night or later, seven days a week. WOI runs from
6:00 a.m. until local sunset, and W0I-PM runs from
ip:00 p.m. until 11:00 at night. When things are
going well, this is fine, but when we blow a gasket,
the shrieks and moans are wonderful to hear.
Best wishes to you and yours for a Merry Christmas
and a happy and successful New Year!
Sincerely
Richard B. Hull
